displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: which will see where it is. So we put a little radioactive tag- Patient: Okay. Doctor: and the only PSMA does is go from the surface inside the cancer cell, and it’s almost, it’s almost a way to build something up inside. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we can get a really nice picture. Well, the next easy lead from there is why not put something that’s a killer mode. Uh what they’ve seen, and what’s been published in the German, mostly Germany, it’s relatively nontoxic. Uh the big toxicity has been uh the salivary glands seem to make PSMA also. So some people end up with dry mouth uh as a side effect. Uh the kidney also makes P- PSMA. They haven’t really reported acute kidney damage, hasn’t really been a big issue, but they haven’t really followed the people long enough I think to know- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: You know, if down the road if there are kidney problems. At least what they’ve reported so far they don’t - they don’t see it. Patient: I see. Doctor: So I would say the procedure, I normally do it on the trials, but I had this experience with the guys in Germany. What they do is they bring you there and they scan you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: With the imaging part. They see how active is your cancer. How much of the stuff is there on PSMA.

Family Member: That’s an immunotherapy? Doctor: No that’s a it’s a PARP inhibitor which is known to produce really good responses with this medication, with the BRCA mutant prostate cancer. Okay? Patient: Including BRCA2? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: That’s the one we had the article about. Doctor: Yeah, so I think you know that is sort of the somewhat well paved route. Okay because it’s known that the response rates are likely to be pretty good. The other way is -- Patient: Would I continue on the Xtandi in that case or not? Family Member: Okay but she said there’s a third choice. Patient: Just a second, just a second, just a second I’m digesting this. Family Member: Sorry. Patient: Thank you. Ah… Doctor: I know it’s a lot of things to go through.

Patient: You know? So I mean you know I went for years without pain and when my back started hurting again I just that’s the first place I went. Doctor: Of course. Patient: You know, uh, but, uh. Healthcare Professional: Ask them to do soft tissue. I don’t know if they do soft tissue techniques but anything soft tissue… Patient: They got, you know, but I would look into masseuse a um. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Now the chemo, you know, we weren’t going to do any trial just once every three weeks over an hour. Totally doable. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But you know I never just do the standard routine anything. (Laughs) Patient: I been here long enough, I just, I am not new here. Doctor: Yes. So there is uh you know the trial is two-thirds of the people get vitamin C, Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: high dose. So this stuff comes out of Hopkins you know from a special company. It took us forever to do it. But the grade of vitamin C is great.

Patient: Uh-huh, yes, uh-huh. Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I’ve been working, and, uh, I got off work a little early today to come to the appointment, so. Doctor: Okay. Okay. Fine. Patient: And stuff like that. Yep. I’m just staying on course, believing in myself, believing in God, as usual. Doctor: Right. Patient: I know it’s going to get better. Doctor: Alright. Patient: Uh, uh, yes. Doctor: So we have to watch you closely. I don’t know whether, how much, how much you remember when we talked about the pathology and that it invaded the seminal vesicle. Do you remember that discussion? Patient: Yeah. You were saying something, about something, something. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. It went into the seminal vesicle and so, uh, we’re going to have to just, just watch you closely. Right now, everything is fine and it may continue to be that way. Okay?

Patient: Right. I don’t have to be a rabbit anymore? We might have to change this little tail that I’m growing. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: He lost seven pounds in a week. (Laughter) Doctor: It’s really key. Don’t let people take your money for crazy stuff. Patient: Right, okay. Family Member: We’re just afraid, to be honest with you, is like you know we feel a little helpless here this conversation with you, but I think what we’re trying to do is like figure out ____ like what can I do to like to cause it to get worse. Doctor: Stay thin. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It’s that simple. I mean when you look across all the thousands of guys with prostate cancer and all the different things out there, the bottom line is don’t get fat. Patient: Right, okay. Doctor: And how will you do that? It doesn’t matter. It’s the fact that you don’t. Patient: Right. Family Member: And now I have a question, and you can tell me if you know how to answer this but you know you’re saying here you’re giving us all our options. Is your heart in one place and the other with standard of care two versus the chemo and super hormone for somebody like him?

Patient: these three, four, five, six session of chemo – Doctor: Um, hmm. Patient: - what would be the best result in your opinion? Doctor: Well that you feel better, the PSA goes down to zero and the next imaging scans are rock stable. That’d be a homerun. It won’t ever really go away you know these things don’t change. Patient: The metastatic areas we see on the bones… Doctor: They’re there forever. Patient: They’re there… Doctor: They’re there forever. Patient: Yep. Doctor: But if your PSA is zero and you feel good, it’s controlled. Patient: Okay, okay. Doctor: I’ll take control and we can ease up on the chemo or give you a holiday for several months and then homerun. Patient: Okay, okay. But it never will go in remission, it will never be gone?

Family Member: Right. Doctor: - that he has. Family Member: Exactly. Doctor: That’s basically still there. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But because the PSA was doing a little bit of this creep up- Family Member: Creep up. Um hum. Doctor: We rechecked him. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And then he’s got a couple of new spots in the bone which just happens to be in your skull. Family Member: Wow. Doctor: Which is, you know, no different than it is in the leg and what not but it’s a signal to us.

Patient: Legs, mostly the legs, a little bit in the back, but I wanted to address the fatigue. That’s really… Doctor: Yeah, you just feel wiped out? Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Is that still a reaction from radiation six months ago? Doctor: No. Family Member: No, He shouldn’t have any effects from the radiation at this point? Doctor: No, I mean the only sort of culprit is untreated prostate cancer. You know if I had to sort of go back and we go a round of a bunch of pills Patient: Right. Doctor: radiation but that time has passed and I’m just gonna recap where we are so we have a plan. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I told you you’re making me work hard. Patient: I know. Doctor: But I’ve been thinking about you since we can’t get these trials to gel and I told the gals over there I said listen the minute we’re kind of fumbling around, stop, back here. Because we have to reset in our ways because we’re not losing time but I hate not having a plan and you guys hate not having a plan.

Patient: Okay. Healthcare Professional: For that your records. Family Member: So, the copy we got in the mail, it might be the same thing. Healthcare Professional: It should be probably different. (pause) Doctor: And do you have a local pharmacy you use? Patient: Yeah, it’s Rite Aid F___. Doctor: Two r’s or one r in F___? Patient: Two. No, it’s just one. Doctor: And do you know the zip for F___? Patient: No. Family Member: Umm, two oh five oh, maybe? (pause) Doctor: F___ five - one five two zero R____.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Then you and I just have to pick a day when you wanna start chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, some of it is, you can look at a calendar. The end of the year is coming. You know, Christmas, New Year’s, Thanksgiving. You know, what day, eh, do you wanna plan it out. ‘Cuz once we get started, it’s gonna be every three weeks. Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay? You’re gonna come in two weeks which would be the twenty-first. You could theoretically get your first chemo then. You may also say, “Uh, no, let’s wait two more weeks.” Patient: Until the third of January or something. Doctor: You could wait until the third of January, or you could -- Patient: Now, if you got - You, you – I grabbed that number out of the air. You can – Doctor: You could try to wait or things like that. Healthcare Professional: Yeah, he could wait. Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Because, again, I like to wait a little bit. Patient: After the, uh, hormones?

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.12 years or completed high school: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::12 years or completed high school

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: Yeah, just out of the blue. It last for a few minutes and then stops. Doctor: Okay, on an average day how many times does that happen or is it not every day? Patient: When I’ve noticed it, it might be once or twice a day. Doctor: Okay, all right. Usually not at night, usually during the day. Patient: No, no. Well it could be the stress or the activity that’s happening in church that might push my level. Doctor: Well your testosterone level is still low. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And it’s creeping up, so about three or four months ago twice in the thirties. The normal testosterone for a man of your age would be around a hundred and fifty or two hundred. When we checked your last blood test about two weeks ago it had gone up to fifty-eight. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So it’s slowly increasing. Patient: Right. Doctor: That would mean at least in theory that your fatigue should begin to get better, although the increase has been very recent, so it may not have given your body the time to adjust to that higher level of testosterone. And with time if you remain off of the hormone therapy like you’re currently doing despite your age it may continue to increase further. Patient: Uh huh.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: And they will likely shrink the disease and, you know, also lower the PSA, and the good thing is they are likely to work for long periods of time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But, the possibility of side effects is a little bit higher. Okay? And usually, those side effects are high blood pressure, leg swelling, low potassium. So, you’re going to have to monitor and stay with the visits because at least for the first few months, we’ll have to monitor you somewhat closer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Once both of us sort of get comfortable, like we did, but you got too comfortable, Doctor: With this medication Patient: Mmm, hmm. Doctor: Then, I will be able to space it further and further apart. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But the first two or three months are going to be somewhat critical. Patient: The same what we did with the Casodex? Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: A month ago, you hadn’t and now you’ve you’ve crossed that number which I think was twenty-six point seven. So you’re two points above that. The second reason is um having to do with your scans. We have the results of your bone scan and your um CAT scan. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The um the bone scan looks completely unchanged, in other words normal. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we don’t think there is any evidence or hint that there could be prostate cancer in the bone. And that is really the most important thing; so I wanted to say that first. The second one is the CAT scan. So on the CAT scan, you have a lymph node inside your abdomen - Patient: Okay. Doctor: - which has slightly increased in size. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. It is probably due to prostate cancer. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: We won’t know for sure unless we do a biopsy, which I’m not recommending. Patient: Okay.

Healthcare Professional: Oh, I’m so sorry. Doctor: Not blood? Patient: Not blood, no. That's all I know about it. I mean, I just know that it’s not a good thing. Healthcare Professional: Do you have a feeling about it? Do you have a preference? Would you prefer to stay on the blood thinner? Patient: I just think- I just renewed it. Healthcare Professional: Oh. Patient: So I think I'll stay the course and then we'll see what happens after that. Because I'm pretty good watching. If anything is swelling or if I’m having any pain. I'll be a little more vigilant now to go to the doctor whereas before I'm like. Doctor: Hopefully it doesn’t happen while you’re on the medicine. Patient: Right, no, I'm saying if I got off of it, I'd be a little more vigilant about the idea that if I have swelling, I should go to the doctor because it might not just be me being a macho jock, but I have a problem. Doctor: And so what I hear you say- is that you just got a prescription and how long is that going to be for? Patient: I think that's for three more months. Doctor: So that would be your plan to sort of go and then stop for six months. Healthcare Professional: Okay

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Umm. So, that would be sort of, in some ways, a gamble. But, some folks, everything we know about the drugs you’ve had so far, we’ve had people gamble at one point. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And, then, the third one is we draw blood tests today, just to see the AR-V7 positive. That maybe that you say in what you’re doing now, and if you are AR-V7 positive, then we can sort of say, “Hey, yeah, let’s look at this other option,” if the immune therapy would be something that you would think about. Patient: Okay. What, what, what’s the, uh, uh, um likelihood of, of, if at that time the AR-V7, uh, testing comes back negative which means I can’t do that. Doctor: Right. Patient: Uh, and then look at the other options. So, is that, is the one that is phase one is that, that window like a real tight window. That seven days from now, it’s gonna be closed? Doctor: Umm. I don’t know that. So, when I spoke to Dr. P_, all she let me know was that there was a slot. You know, that would be something that we would say once you’ve decided or that we’ve given you the consent form that we have a potential patient who’s interested, that they would save that slot for you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because they would, I assume, that there is going to need to be a twenty-eight day washout of your current therapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then, maybe that you have to repeat scans prior to that. Um, the adrenal glands. The, the big wild card there right now what I can clearly state that it is not specific. I don’t know what it is.
